{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3135510,"name":"Jeff","username":"Jeff_2450","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jeff_2450/{size}/166688_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-28T20:05:05.674Z","cooked":"

Hi y’all, our programmers are trying to get the Thrifty Bot Encoders to work with the Swerve Drive Specialties Mk4i. However the Swerve Drive Specialties library is built to be used with CANCoders, Are there any teams that are using the SDS library but with TTB analog encoders instead of the CANCoders?

You matter.","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3135520,"name":"Fletch","username":"Fletch1373","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/fletch1373/{size}/220073_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-28T20:20:22.084Z","cooked":"

I presume you’re using this encoder (I’ve never used it, so just wanted to make sure we’re talking about the same thing)

If you look at the User Guide, it explains that it’s simply an analog input to the RoboRio (or the sensor port on a SparkMax or TalonSRX if using one of those). From there, you create an AnalogEncoder object and configure it. Then you need to tell SDS how to get the value (specifics on how to do that would require seeing your code, preferably as a link to github or similar)

Here is our github

Here’s a file that defines our interface.

github.com

FRC5010/FRCLibrary/blob/main/FRC5010Example2023/src/main/java/frc/robot/FRC5010/sensors/AnalogInput5010.java

// Copyright (c) FIRST and other WPILib contributors.
// Open Source Software; you can modify and/or share it under the terms of
// the WPILib BSD license file in the root directory of this project.

package frc.robot.FRC5010.sensors;

import edu.wpi.first.wpilibj.AnalogInput;
import edu.wpi.first.wpilibj.RobotController;
import frc.robot.FRC5010.sensors.encoder.GenericEncoder;

/** Add your docs here. */
public class AnalogInput5010 implements GenericEncoder{

    AnalogInput analogInput;
    boolean inverted;

    public AnalogInput5010(int port){
        analogInput = new AnalogInput(port);
        inverted = false;
    }
This file has been truncated. show original

The formula in getPosition is mainly what you want.
However, your right, the SDS Library code doesn’t support using that directly. You have to write more general swerve module code, I believe.

Thanks for sharing your module! This will be super helpful.

And yes, the hardest part we anticipate is going to be creating the classes to fit into the SDS library. A lot of factory patterm/polymorphism at hand that we just have to make sure we fit into.

If we get something working we intend on publishing our additions to the library.
